title: How to Grow Runner Beans

steps.headline: Purchase a packet of runner bean seeds from a local garden center.
steps.description: Runner beans come in a wide range of varieties, each offering different qualities. Some offer a traditional flavor, others are known for being highly ornamental, and some are dwarf varieties. Pick out 1 or 2 packets of dried seeds for the variety you’d like to grow from a local garden center. Try the old and well-known Scarlet Emperor variety for a traditional flavor. Consider the White Lady or Painted Lady varieties for a decorative effect. These plants produce white or white and red flowers, respectively. If you’d like to try growing beans that aren’t green, try a variety like Blauhilde which produces purple bean pods.

steps.headline: Fill small pots with rich soil and 1 to 3 runner bean seeds.
steps.description: Choose pots measuring about 2.5 to 3 in (6.4 to 7.6 cm) in diameter. Fill these with multipurpose soil or a mixture of soil and compost. Press between 1 to 3 seeds into the soil until they sit about 2 in (5.1 cm) below the surface. Cover them back over with soil and give them an initial watering. Start this process in mid-April or early May.

steps.headline: Nourish the seeds with regular waterings and a warm, sunny environment.
steps.description: Place the small pots in a greenhouse or on a sunny window ledge. Choose a warm spot that reaches over 54 °F (12 °C). Keep the soil moist by watering it on a daily basis. The seeds will begin to germinate after about 1 week.

steps.headline: Harden off the seedlings by gradually exposing them to cooler temperatures.
steps.description: Once the pots contain healthy, leafy seedlings, you’ll need to harden them off before transferring them outside. Move the pots to a cold greenhouse or place them in a cold frame, and keep the glass open during the day but closed at night. Alternatively, place the pot outside along a south-facing wall during the day and return it inside at night. Start by covering the seedlings with a cloche or 1 or 2 layers of fleece at first, then reduce the coverings after a week or 2. Continue exposing the seedlings to cooler temperatures over the course of 1 to 3 weeks.

steps.headline: Plant the seedlings outside between mid-May and July.
steps.description: Wait until after the last frost before transplanting your seedlings in outdoor soil. Plant the strongest seedlings first and continue growing or hardening off the less mature ones. Tip the pot over to release the seedling. Place the soil-covered roots into a divot within your bean trench. Then cover the roots and the base of the seedling with soil. Situate 1 plant near each cane support leaving around 6 in (15 cm) of space between seedlings. Continue transplanting more seedlings through July to extend the harvesting period.

steps.headline: Choose an outdoor patch of deep, fertile soil that receives direct sunlight.
steps.description: Runner beans need a lot of nourishment, so avoid planting them in weak, infertile soil. Find a spot that receives continual sunlight throughout the day, but that’s protected from the wind. Excessive wind may damage your support structure and the plants climbing it. To prepare less fertile soil for a bean trench, mix compost into the soil during the previous autumn.

steps.headline: Dig a 2 ft (0.61 m) deep bean trench.
steps.description: Mark out a line for your bean trench measuring at least 3 ft (0.91 m) long. Dig the trench using a garden shovel or another digging tool until it’s about. 2 ft (0.61 m) deep. Don’t make the trench particularly wide; keep it less than 1 ft (0.30 m) wide. Use a gardening fork to loosen up the soil at the base of your bean trench. If you want to plant multiple rows, leave about 5 feet of space between each trench.

steps.headline: Blend compost into the soil and let it warm up for 2 weeks.
steps.description: Enrich your soil prior to transplanting your runner bean seedlings. Spread homemade compost or manure fertilizer into the bean trench to deliver more nutrients. Allow the soil and compost to settle for about 14 days. During this resting period, cover the soil with a plastic sheet or cloche to keep it warm if necessary. The soil should reach about 50 °F (10 °C) by the time you’re ready to start sowing.

steps.headline: Purchase canes for your chosen support structure.
steps.description: Pick up hazel poles or bamboo canes measuring about 8 ft (2.4 m) tall from a local garden center. If you have a small garden or want to plant just a few runner bean plants in a short bean trench, plan on creating 1 or more wigwam supports. Get 3 to 4 canes for each wigwam support. If you’d like to plant 1 or more long bean trenches, plan to create an X-shaped tunnel of crisscrossed canes. Pick up 4 canes for each 1 ft (0.30 m) of your bean trench. If you’d like to wrap the support structure with netting, pick up some polyethylene trellis netting with gaps measuring approximately 4 to 5 in (10 to 13 cm). This will give the beans an additional foundation to climb up.

steps.headline: Create holes for your canes using a sturdy pole.
steps.description: Whether you’re creating a tunnel or wigwam support, prep the ground with holes. Use a metal pipe or sturdy plastic rod, ideally with a pointed edge, to create a space for your canes to sit in. Push the pole at least 6 in (15 cm) deep into the soil and jostle it around to open up space in the ground. Measure out the space between each cane, according to your chosen support style, before you start creating the holes. By using this technique, you won’t have to push too hard on the canes and risk snapping them. Avoid creating too large a hole or else your canes won’t stand up properly.

steps.headline: Secure canes on either side of your bean trench into a long, X-shaped tunnel.
steps.description: Place 1 cane on either side of the trench, leaving around 18 in (46 cm) of space between the 2 canes. Lean them in towards each other until the tops cross. Secure them together using twine or a zip-tie. Situate another pair of canes about 6 in (15 cm) away from the first. Continue adding crisscrossed canes until you create a tunnel that covers the whole trench. Secure 1 or more horizontal canes over the top of the tunnel to provide stability. If you have a larger vegetable garden, use this strategy to create a long tunnel of canes for your runner beans to climb up and around. Secure the canes closer towards the top for more of an A-shaped frame, or tie them in the middle if you prefer a pronounced X-shape.

steps.headline: Create smaller wigwam supports over your bean trench.
steps.description: This technique is great for gardens with limited space. Use 3 to 4 canes per wigwam. Arrange them in a circle in the soil, with each cane sitting about 2 feet apart. Secure the canes together at the top using twine or a zip-tie. Feel free to plant 1 or 2 seedlings under 1 wigwam support in a large planter pot if you don’t have enough space for a bean trench. Use 2 or more wigwam supports to cover a long bean trench or multiple rows of trenches.

steps.headline: Add trellis netting to give your runner beans additional climbing space.
steps.description: Choose a polyethylene trellis netting with openings measuring about 4 to 5 in (10 to 13 cm). Look for one that’s designed for use with beans and peas. Drape a length of netting over an existing cane support structure or ready-made trellis. Secure it with twine, zip-ties, or twist-ties. Keep in mind that if you wrap trellis netting around a wigwam structure or tunnel, it will be harder to reach into the center area.

steps.headline: Keep the soil moist with regular watering and mulching.
steps.description: Water the runner beans every other day with about 1 to 2 gallons of water per square yard of soil (5 to 9 liters of water per square meter of soil). Scatter a full layer of mulch over the top of the soil to trap in some of the moisture. Drought or dry soil will prevent the beans from thriving. Add liquid fertilizer once every 2 weeks to encourage bean pod growth.

steps.headline: Tie the vines around the support structure to encourage climbing.
steps.description: Use a piece of twine or a twist-tie to secure young seedlings to the canes. More mature vines can be tied down as well to prevent wind disturbances. Once they start growing, runner beans will naturally climb up the canes and coil themselves around the supports.

steps.headline: Pinch out the top of the plant once it reaches the top of the support.
steps.description: Pinching out the vine will stop it from getting too top-heavy. It also encourages the plant to grow outwards rather than upwards and focus its energy on pod production. Cut off the tip of each vine where you see 2 leaves sprouting. Feel free to compost these discarded tips.

steps.headline: Harvest the bean pods once they’re 6 to 8 inches long.
steps.description: You’ll be able to start harvesting bean pods around 12 to 16 weeks after sowing. Pick the bean pods every other day to encourage more production. Don’t wait until the beam pods reach maturity; pick them when they’re still tender, and when the seeds inside are relatively small. Snap off the bean pods gently to detach them from the vine. You can start harvesting in mid-summer if you sowed the seeds in spring, and you may be able to continue until the first frost in autumn. If you don’t harvest regularly, the plant will stop producing new bean pods and flowers. Fully mature bean pods are more likely to be tough and stringy.
